title: TRESA Compliance Requirements
content: All real estate professionals must comply with TRESA requirements including mandatory representation agreements, disclosure obligations, and professional conduct standards. Non-compliance may result in disciplinary action.

title: Buyer Representation Agreement Rules
content: Real estate professionals must have a signed buyer representation agreement before showing properties. The agreement must clearly outline commission arrangements, duties, and term of representation.

title: Disclosure Obligations
content: Real estate professionals must disclose all material facts, conflicts of interest, and commission arrangements. Failure to disclose may result in penalties and legal liability.

title: Professional Conduct Standards
content: TRESA establishes higher professional conduct standards including continuing education requirements, ethical obligations, and client service standards.

title: Complaint and Discipline Process
content: RECO investigates complaints against real estate professionals. The process includes investigation, mediation, and disciplinary hearings with potential penalties including fines and license suspension.

title: Consumer Protection Measures
content: TRESA includes enhanced consumer protection measures such as mandatory written agreements, clear disclosure requirements, and improved complaint resolution processes.

title: Commission Disclosure Rules
content: All commission arrangements must be clearly disclosed in writing. Real estate professionals must explain how commissions are calculated and paid in buyer representation agreements.

title: Licensing and Registration
content: All real estate professionals must be licensed and registered under TRESA. Licensing requirements include education, examination, and ongoing professional development.

title: Record Keeping Requirements
content: Real estate professionals must maintain detailed records of all transactions, agreements, and client communications as required under TRESA regulations.

title: Penalties and Enforcement
content: TRESA violations can result in administrative penalties, fines up to $50,000 for individuals and $100,000 for corporations, license suspension or revocation, and criminal charges for serious offenses.

title: Administrative Penalties Framework
content: Administrative penalties up to $25,000 can be imposed for TRESA violations without requiring a criminal conviction. These penalties promote compliance and prevent economic benefit from violations. Payment prevents criminal charges for the same violation.

title: Lien and Collection Powers
content: If fines or administrative penalties remain unpaid for 60+ days, the director can create liens against personal and real property, report to credit agencies, and enforce collection through court orders.

title: Insurance and Financial Security
content: TRESA requires brokerages, brokers, and salespersons to maintain prescribed insurance coverage, bonds, or collateral security. This may include mandatory participation in group insurance programs.

title: Trust Account Management
content: Brokerages must maintain trust accounts in compliance with prescribed rules. Regulations govern account management, record keeping, and procedures for winding down accounts when registration ends.

title: Multiple Representation Rules
content: TRESA governs when real estate professionals can represent multiple parties in a transaction. Specific disclosure requirements and prohibited circumstances are prescribed by regulation.

title: Specialization Certification
content: Real estate professionals can obtain specialist certifications in prescribed areas. Requirements include specialized education, testing, and ongoing maintenance of certification standards.

title: Information Disclosure to Registrar
content: Registrants must provide requested information to the registrar about trades, business operations, and interested parties. Information must be provided in prescribed forms and verified by affidavit when required.

title: Confidentiality and Information Protection
content: Information obtained in administering TRESA must be kept confidential except for legal proceedings, administration purposes, consumer protection, or law enforcement activities.

title: Service of Legal Documents
content: Legal notices and orders under TRESA can be served personally, by registered mail, or other provable methods. Registered mail service is deemed effective on the third day after mailing.

title: Appeals and Hearing Rights
content: Administrative penalty orders can be appealed within 15 days. The appeal body conducts hearings and can confirm, revoke, or vary penalties. Appeals don't automatically stay enforcement.

title: Registration Conditions and Requirements
content: TRESA registration includes prescribed conditions, education requirements, and ongoing compliance obligations. Violations can result in additional conditions, suspension, or revocation.

title: Quality Assurance Programs
content: The director and administrative authority can conduct quality assurance programs to monitor compliance and use collected information to improve administration and enforcement.

title: Electronic Commerce Compliance
content: TRESA regulations govern how electronic commerce laws apply to real estate transactions, ensuring digital processes meet legal requirements for contracts and disclosures.

title: Exemptions and Special Circumstances
content: Regulations may exempt certain persons or classes of trades from TRESA requirements with prescribed conditions. Exemptions are granted based on specific criteria and public interest considerations.

title: Transitional Provisions
content: TRESA includes provisions for transitioning from previous legislation, handling existing registrations, and ensuring continuity during regulatory changes and implementation.
